sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Jordan is a country located in Western Asia, known for its ancient history, desert landscapes, and role as a cultural crossroads of the Middle East.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Amman is the capital and largest city of Jordan. It is the country’s political, economic, and cultural center.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency of Jordan is the Jordanian dinar (JOD).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Arabic. English is widely understood and commonly used in education and business.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Jordanian cuisine is known for its rich flavors and hospitality, with popular dishes such as mansaf, falafel, and maqluba.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Jordan features deserts, fertile valleys, highlands, and the Jordan Rift Valley. It is also home to part of the Dead Sea, the lowest point on land.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Jordanian culture emphasizes hospitality, family ties, and tradition, influenced by Arab, Islamic, and Bedouin heritage.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourist attractions include the ancient city of Petra, Wadi Rum desert, the Dead Sea, Jerash ruins, and historic Islamic sites.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Petra, one of Jordan’s most famous landmarks, is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.

history.event: Ancient kingdoms such as Edom, Moab, and Ammon existed in the region.
The Nabataean Kingdom rose to power, with Petra as its capital.
The Roman Empire annexed Nabataea, developing cities such as Jerash.
Islam spread through the region, becoming a key part of Jordan’s identity.
Jordan came under Ottoman rule for several centuries.
The Emirate of Transjordan was established under British supervision.
Jordan gained independence and became the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
